Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 9, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Between you and the rest of the world 
lies an interface that makes up 16% of your physical weight. This is your skin, the largest organ 
in your body: laid out flat, it would cover close to 
1.7 square meters of ground. Its purpose may seem obvious—
to keep our insides in. But a look beyond the surface reveals that it plays a surprising 
number of roles in our lives. First, the basics. Skin is the foundation 
of the integumentary system, which also incorporates your hair, 
nails, and specialized glands and nerves. Made up of three layers, the epidermis, dermis, and hypodermis, skin’s thickness varies 
from 0.5 millimeters at its thinnest and up to four millimeters 
at its thickest. It also carries out three key functions: protecting, regulating, and sensing the world beyond its limits. On a daily basis, its huge surface 
processes hundreds, if not thousands, of physical sensations, relying mostly on large, 
pressure-sensitive skin components called Merkel cells. In your fingertips alone, there are 750 Merkel cells 
per each square-centimeter of skin, coupled with over 2,500 receptors
that give you your sense of touch. This surface is also the body’s first 
major line of defense. Without it, you’d be a soggy mass 
of tissue and fluids, fatally exposed to the elements. Skin effectively seals off your insides and also absorbs pressure and shock with flexible collagen 
that makes up most of its dermal layer. The epidermis is made up mainly 
of skin cells called keratinocytes that are completely replaced 
every four weeks. As new cells form at the base of the
epidermis, older ones are pushed up. When these cells move upwards, they’re filled with a hardened protein 
called keratin. Once they reach the surface, they form a tightly-overlapping, 
waterproof layer that’s difficult for invading 
microbes to breach. Any harmful microbes that make it 
into the epidermis will encounter Langerhans cells. This group of protective skin cells 
detects invaders and communicates their presence 
to resident immune system T-cells, which react by launching 
an immune response. A crucial feature of this immune defense is the several thousand 
species of microorganisms that inhabit the planes, folds, and crevices of your skin. These microbes, 
which include bacteria and fungi, thrive in the sebum, an oily substance that’s secreted 
onto the skin’s surface by sebaceous glands nestled
inside the dermis. These skin microbes keep the immune system
in a state of constant surveillance, ensuring that it’s ready to react 
if the body really is at risk. Beyond this protective role, your skin is also a sensory organ that
helps regulate your body’s temperature, two roles that are closely interlinked. Nerves detect whether your skin 
is warm or cold and communicate that
information to your brain. In return, the brain instructs
localized blood vessels to either expand if the body is too warm, releasing heat from 
the blood through the skin, or to constrict if the body is cold,
which retains heat. At any given time, up to 25% of the body's
blood is circulating through the dermis, making this process extremely efficient. Under warm conditions, the skin’s sweat glands will secrete sweat
via ducts onto the surface, transferring heat out of the body. Hair can also be stimulated
to conserve or release body warmth. The average human 
has 5 million hair follicles embedded everywhere on the body except the palms of your hands 
and soles of your feet. Ninety to 150,000 of those 
are on your scalp, where they help shield
the large surface area of your head from physical damage and sunburn. When you're cold, tiny muscles 
called arrector pilli cause hair to stand upright
across the body. That’s the phenomenon known as goosebumps
and it traps body heat close to your skin. Skin’s vast surface isn’t just a shield; it also enables us to interact 
and connect with the world. Its multifunctional layer cools us down
and keeps us warm. The integumentary system 
may be many things, but it’s certainly more than skin deep.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: We rely on ______ to give us our sense of touch.
Options: A. The skin’s enormous surface area, B. The sensitive hairs on the surface of our skin, C. Collagen fibers, D. Merkel cells and nerve cells
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What percentage of the human body's physical weight is made up of skin? Options: A. 10%, B. 16%, C. 20%, D. 25% Correct Option: None
Question 2: What is the main function of the Merkel cells in the skin? Options: A. To regulate body temperature, B. To protect the body from external damage, C. To process physical sensations, D. To aid in the production of sweat Correct Option: None
Question 3: What is the primary function of the Langerhans cells in the skin? Options: A. To produce keratin, B. To detect and respond to invading microbes, C. To regulate body temperature, D. To produce sebum Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is the purpose of the microorganisms that inhabit the skin? Options: A. To cause infections, B. To produce sebum, C. To keep the immune system in a state of constant surveillance, D. To regulate body temperature Correct Option: None
Question 5: How does the skin help regulate body temperature? Options: A. By producing sweat to cool the body down, B. By constricting blood vessels to retain heat, C. By expanding blood vessels to release heat, D. All of the above Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is the function of the arrector pili muscles in the skin? Options: A. To cause hair to stand upright and trap body heat, B. To produce sebum, C. To regulate body temperature, D. To detect and respond to invading microbes Correct Option: None
Question 7: How many hair follicles are embedded on the average human body? Options: A. 1 million, B. 5 million, C. 10 million, D. 20 million Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is the primary function of the keratinocytes in the epidermis? Options: A. To produce keratin, B. To detect and respond to invading microbes, C. To regulate body temperature, D. To form a tightly-overlapping, waterproof layer Correct Option: None
Question 9: How often are the skin cells in the epidermis completely replaced? Options: A. Every week, B. Every two weeks, C. Every four weeks, D. Every six weeks Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the name of the oily substance secreted onto the skin's surface by sebaceous glands? Options: A. Sebum, B. Keratin, C. Collagen, D. Sweat Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 2. 

Although the wording of the question is different, the intent of Question 2 is similar to the ground truth MCQ, as it asks about the function of Merkel cells in the skin. The correct answer to the ground truth MCQ is "D. Merkel cells and nerve cells," which is similar to the correct function of Merkel cells described in Question 2, which is "C. To process physical sensations." 

However, it's worth noting that the options provided in Question 2 do not exactly match the options in the ground truth MCQ. Nevertheless, based on the content and intent of the question, Question 2 is the most similar generated MCQ to the ground truth MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 9, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Between you and the rest of the world 
lies an interface that makes up 16% of your physical weight. This is your skin, the largest organ 
in your body: laid out flat, it would cover close to 
1.7 square meters of ground. Its purpose may seem obvious—
to keep our insides in. But a look beyond the surface reveals that it plays a surprising 
number of roles in our lives. First, the basics. Skin is the foundation 
of the integumentary system, which also incorporates your hair, 
nails, and specialized glands and nerves. Made up of three layers, the epidermis, dermis, and hypodermis, skin’s thickness varies 
from 0.5 millimeters at its thinnest and up to four millimeters 
at its thickest. It also carries out three key functions: protecting, regulating, and sensing the world beyond its limits. On a daily basis, its huge surface 
processes hundreds, if not thousands, of physical sensations, relying mostly on large, 
pressure-sensitive skin components called Merkel cells. In your fingertips alone, there are 750 Merkel cells 
per each square-centimeter of skin, coupled with over 2,500 receptors
that give you your sense of touch. This surface is also the body’s first 
major line of defense. Without it, you’d be a soggy mass 
of tissue and fluids, fatally exposed to the elements. Skin effectively seals off your insides and also absorbs pressure and shock with flexible collagen 
that makes up most of its dermal layer. The epidermis is made up mainly 
of skin cells called keratinocytes that are completely replaced 
every four weeks. As new cells form at the base of the
epidermis, older ones are pushed up. When these cells move upwards, they’re filled with a hardened protein 
called keratin. Once they reach the surface, they form a tightly-overlapping, 
waterproof layer that’s difficult for invading 
microbes to breach. Any harmful microbes that make it 
into the epidermis will encounter Langerhans cells. This group of protective skin cells 
detects invaders and communicates their presence 
to resident immune system T-cells, which react by launching 
an immune response. A crucial feature of this immune defense is the several thousand 
species of microorganisms that inhabit the planes, folds, and crevices of your skin. These microbes, 
which include bacteria and fungi, thrive in the sebum, an oily substance that’s secreted 
onto the skin’s surface by sebaceous glands nestled
inside the dermis. These skin microbes keep the immune system
in a state of constant surveillance, ensuring that it’s ready to react 
if the body really is at risk. Beyond this protective role, your skin is also a sensory organ that
helps regulate your body’s temperature, two roles that are closely interlinked. Nerves detect whether your skin 
is warm or cold and communicate that
information to your brain. In return, the brain instructs
localized blood vessels to either expand if the body is too warm, releasing heat from 
the blood through the skin, or to constrict if the body is cold,
which retains heat. At any given time, up to 25% of the body's
blood is circulating through the dermis, making this process extremely efficient. Under warm conditions, the skin’s sweat glands will secrete sweat
via ducts onto the surface, transferring heat out of the body. Hair can also be stimulated
to conserve or release body warmth. The average human 
has 5 million hair follicles embedded everywhere on the body except the palms of your hands 
and soles of your feet. Ninety to 150,000 of those 
are on your scalp, where they help shield
the large surface area of your head from physical damage and sunburn. When you're cold, tiny muscles 
called arrector pilli cause hair to stand upright
across the body. That’s the phenomenon known as goosebumps
and it traps body heat close to your skin. Skin’s vast surface isn’t just a shield; it also enables us to interact 
and connect with the world. Its multifunctional layer cools us down
and keeps us warm. The integumentary system 
may be many things, but it’s certainly more than skin deep.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The integumentary system is made up of ______.
Options: A. The skin, B. The hair, skin, nails, certain glands, and nerves, C. Everything you see on the surface of your body, D. Your skin and hair
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What percentage of the human body's physical weight is made up of skin? Options: A. 10%, B. 16%, C. 20%, D. 25% Correct Option: None
Question 2: What is the main function of the Merkel cells in the skin? Options: A. To regulate body temperature, B. To protect the body from external damage, C. To process physical sensations, D. To aid in the production of sweat Correct Option: None
Question 3: What is the primary function of the Langerhans cells in the skin? Options: A. To produce keratin, B. To detect and respond to invading microbes, C. To regulate body temperature, D. To produce sebum Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is the purpose of the microorganisms that inhabit the skin? Options: A. To cause infections, B. To produce sebum, C. To keep the immune system in a state of constant surveillance, D. To regulate body temperature Correct Option: None
Question 5: How does the skin help regulate body temperature? Options: A. By producing sweat to cool the body down, B. By constricting blood vessels to retain heat, C. By expanding blood vessels to release heat, D. All of the above Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is the function of the arrector pili muscles in the skin? Options: A. To cause hair to stand upright and trap body heat, B. To produce sebum, C. To regulate body temperature, D. To detect and respond to invading microbes Correct Option: None
Question 7: How many hair follicles are embedded on the average human body? Options: A. 1 million, B. 5 million, C. 10 million, D. 20 million Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is the primary function of the keratinocytes in the epidermis? Options: A. To produce keratin, B. To detect and respond to invading microbes, C. To regulate body temperature, D. To form a tightly-overlapping, waterproof layer Correct Option: None
Question 9: How often are the skin cells in the epidermis completely replaced? Options: A. Every week, B. Every two weeks, C. Every four weeks, D. Every six weeks Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the name of the oily substance secreted onto the skin's surface by sebaceous glands? Options: A. Sebum, B. Keratin, C. Collagen, D. Sweat Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
None of the generated MCQs directly match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question content, options, and overall intent. However, I can try to find the one that is closest in terms of relevance to the integumentary system.

The ground truth MCQ asks about the composition of the integumentary system. While none of the generated MCQs ask this exact question, some of them do relate to components of the integumentary system.

Based on this analysis, I would say that none of the generated MCQs are a good match for the ground truth MCQ. However, if I had to choose one, I would say that Question 7 is the closest, as it relates to hair follicles, which are part of the integumentary system. But it's still not a good match.

A better approach would be to generate new MCQs that directly address the composition of the integumentary system.

may be many things, but it’s certainly more than skin deep.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 9, Question 6

Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. Between you and the rest of the world 
lies an interface that makes up 16% of your physical weight. This is your skin, the largest organ 
in your body: laid out flat, it would cover close to 
1.7 square meters of ground. Its purpose may seem obvious—
to keep our insides in. But a look beyond the surface reveals that it plays a surprising 
number of roles in our lives. First, the basics. Skin is the foundation 
of the integumentary system, which also incorporates your hair, 
nails, and specialized glands and nerves. Made up of three layers, the epidermis, dermis, and hypodermis, skin’s thickness varies 
from 0.5 millimeters at its thinnest and up to four millimeters 
at its thickest. It also carries out three key functions: protecting, regulating, and sensing the world beyond its limits. On a daily basis, its huge surface 
processes hundreds, if not thousands, of physical sensations, relying mostly on large, 
pressure-sensitive skin components called Merkel cells. In your fingertips alone, there are 750 Merkel cells 
per each square-centimeter of skin, coupled with over 2,500 receptors
that give you your sense of touch. This surface is also the body’s first 
major line of defense. Without it, you’d be a soggy mass 
of tissue and fluids, fatally exposed to the elements. Skin effectively seals off your insides and also absorbs pressure and shock with flexible collagen 
that makes up most of its dermal layer. The epidermis is made up mainly 
of skin cells called keratinocytes that are completely replaced 
every four weeks. As new cells form at the base of the
epidermis, older ones are pushed up. When these cells move upwards, they’re filled with a hardened protein 
called keratin. Once they reach the surface, they form a tightly-overlapping, 
waterproof layer that’s difficult for invading 
microbes to breach. Any harmful microbes that make it 
into the epidermis will encounter Langerhans cells. This group of protective skin cells 
detects invaders and communicates their presence 
to resident immune system T-cells, which react by launching 
an immune response. A crucial feature of this immune defense is the several thousand 
species of microorganisms that inhabit the planes, folds, and crevices of your skin. These microbes, 
which include bacteria and fungi, thrive in the sebum, an oily substance that’s secreted 
onto the skin’s surface by sebaceous glands nestled
inside the dermis. These skin microbes keep the immune system
in a state of constant surveillance, ensuring that it’s ready to react 
if the body really is at risk. Beyond this protective role, your skin is also a sensory organ that
helps regulate your body’s temperature, two roles that are closely interlinked. Nerves detect whether your skin 
is warm or cold and communicate that
information to your brain. In return, the brain instructs
localized blood vessels to either expand if the body is too warm, releasing heat from 
the blood through the skin, or to constrict if the body is cold,
which retains heat. At any given time, up to 25% of the body's
blood is circulating through the dermis, making this process extremely efficient. Under warm conditions, the skin’s sweat glands will secrete sweat
via ducts onto the surface, transferring heat out of the body. Hair can also be stimulated
to conserve or release body warmth. The average human 
has 5 million hair follicles embedded everywhere on the body except the palms of your hands 
and soles of your feet. Ninety to 150,000 of those 
are on your scalp, where they help shield
the large surface area of your head from physical damage and sunburn. When you're cold, tiny muscles 
called arrector pilli cause hair to stand upright
across the body. That’s the phenomenon known as goosebumps
and it traps body heat close to your skin. Skin’s vast surface isn’t just a shield; it also enables us to interact 
and connect with the world. Its multifunctional layer cools us down
and keeps us warm. The integumentary system 
may be many things, but it’s certainly more than skin deep.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Your skin is your body’s largest organ.
Options: A. True, B. False
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What percentage of the human body's physical weight is made up of skin? Options: A. 10%, B. 16%, C. 20%, D. 25% Correct Option: None
Question 2: What is the main function of the Merkel cells in the skin? Options: A. To regulate body temperature, B. To protect the body from external damage, C. To process physical sensations, D. To aid in the production of sweat Correct Option: None
Question 3: What is the primary function of the Langerhans cells in the skin? Options: A. To produce keratin, B. To detect and respond to invading microbes, C. To regulate body temperature, D. To produce sebum Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is the purpose of the microorganisms that inhabit the skin? Options: A. To cause infections, B. To produce sebum, C. To keep the immune system in a state of constant surveillance, D. To regulate body temperature Correct Option: None
Question 5: How does the skin help regulate body temperature? Options: A. By producing sweat to cool the body down, B. By constricting blood vessels to retain heat, C. By expanding blood vessels to release heat, D. All of the above Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is the function of the arrector pili muscles in the skin? Options: A. To cause hair to stand upright and trap body heat, B. To produce sebum, C. To regulate body temperature, D. To detect and respond to invading microbes Correct Option: None
Question 7: How many hair follicles are embedded on the average human body? Options: A. 1 million, B. 5 million, C. 10 million, D. 20 million Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is the primary function of the keratinocytes in the epidermis? Options: A. To produce keratin, B. To detect and respond to invading microbes, C. To regulate body temperature, D. To form a tightly-overlapping, waterproof layer Correct Option: None
Question 9: How often are the skin cells in the epidermis completely replaced? Options: A. Every week, B. Every two weeks, C. Every four weeks, D. Every six weeks Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the name of the oily substance secreted onto the skin's surface by sebaceous glands? Options: A. Sebum, B. Keratin, C. Collagen, D. Sweat Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
None of the generated MCQs directly match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question content and options. However, based on the intent and topic, the most similar generated MCQ would be:

This question is related to the ground truth MCQ in that it provides additional information about the skin, which is mentioned as the body's largest organ in the ground truth MCQ. However, it does not directly address the same question.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 10, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
With his harebrained schemes 
and asinine dealings with the gods, King Midas ruled the ancient kingdom 
of Phrygia with an uneven hand. He was known in Greek mythology 
as a rogue ruler whose antics bemused his people 
and distracted the gods. Midas spent his days 
in a stupor of splendor, spoiling himself and his beloved daughter
and gorging himself on feasts and wine. Unsurprisingly, he felt 
an affinity with Dionysus, god of wine, carnival, and performance. One day, Midas discovered a satyr dozing in his rose garden and drunk 
on more than the scent of flowers. Midas recognized the satyr 
as one of Dionysus’s followers and let him nurse 
his hangover at the palace. Pleased with the king’s hospitality,
Dionysus offered to grant him one wish. Midas cast a greedy eye 
over his surroundings. Despite the luxury in which he lived, no amount of precious jewels, finest silk 
or splendid decor felt like enough. His life, he thought, was lacking luster;
what he needed was more gold. The god sent the power to turn anything
the king touched to gold surging through Midas. Ecstatic, he turned to his possessions. At his lightest touch, 
the palace walls transformed, stone statues shone, and goblets glittered. He galloped through his home in a frenzy, handling each item until 
it took on a lustrous sheen. Soon the palace heaved with gold, and Midas’s delirious
laughter echoed off the walls. Exhausted and hungry from his rampage, Midas picked up a bunch of grapes from 
his newly gilded fruit bowl. But he nearly shattered his teeth, for the fruit had turned 
to metal in his mouth. When he picked up a loaf of bread, 
the crumbs hardened in his hand. Flinging himself onto 
his bed in frustration, Midas discovered his plush pillows 
had morphed into solid gold. Hearing his cries of frustration, 
his daughter entered the room. But when Midas reached out to her, he saw with horror that he had frozen her 
into a golden statue. Horrified at what he had done, Midas begged the gods 
to rid him of his power. Taking pity on the foolish king, Dionysus told Midas to wash 
his hands in the River Pactolus. When Midas reached into the river, 
the gold drained from his fingertips. Midas returned home 
to find his daughter alive and his palace back to normal, 
and he rejoiced. You’d think he would’ve learned 
his lesson, but just a few weeks later,
Midas blundered again, insulting the music and sun god Apollo 
when he declared Pan a greater musician. Apollo scornfully declared that the king 
must have the ears of an ass to make such a misjudgment,
and transformed Midas accordingly. Once again regretting his behavior, Midas kept his hairy ears 
hidden in public. They were seen only by his barber, who was sworn to secrecy during 
a very awkward grooming session. The barber stifled his laughter 
and fought the desire to tell someone, yet the secret consumed him. One day, he walked outside the city 
and dug a hole in the ground. Plunging his head into the earth, the desperate barber whispered,
“Midas has ass’s ears.” Soon after, a clump of reeds sprang up in the spot where the barber 
had buried his words. When the wind blew, they carried the 
echoes of his whisper through the breeze: "Midas has ass’s ears." At the sound, donkeys in the fields raised
their heads in recognition and people chuckled to themselves 
at the follies of their king. With his golden touch and ass’s ears, 
Midas was not the most respected ruler. And where other leaders were honored 
through statues and temples, his people remembered him 
a little differently: in the depths of the glittering river 
and the rustle of the Phrygian wind.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Midas was the king of ______.
Options: A. Greece, B. Troy, C. Phrygia, D. Phoenicia
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Who was King Midas in Greek mythology? Options: A. A wise and just ruler of the kingdom of Phrygia., B. A rogue ruler of the kingdom of Phrygia known for his antics and schemes., C. A god of wine and carnival., D. A satyr and follower of Dionysus. Correct Option: None
Question 2: What was King Midas's wish when Dionysus offered to grant him one? Options: A. To have the power to heal any illness., B. To have the power to turn anything he touched to gold., C. To have the power to control the weather., D. To have the power to become invisible. Correct Option: None
Question 3: What happened to King Midas's daughter when he touched her with his golden touch? Options: A. She was turned into a beautiful princess., B. She was turned into a golden statue., C. She was given the power to heal any illness., D. She was given the power to turn anything she touched to gold. Correct Option: None
Question 4: How did King Midas lose his golden touch? Options: A. He was punished by the gods for his greed., B. He was granted a new wish by Dionysus., C. He washed his hands in the River Pactolus., D. He was cursed by a satyr. Correct Option: None
Question 5: What was King Midas's second mistake that led to his transformation? Options: A. He insulted the music and sun god Apollo., B. He praised the music and sun god Apollo., C. He declared Dionysus a greater god than Apollo., D. He declared Pan a lesser musician than Apollo. Correct Option: None
Question 6: What was King Midas transformed into as a result of his second mistake? Options: A. A golden statue., B. A satyr., C. A god., D. A person with the ears of an ass. Correct Option: None
Question 7: Who was the only person who knew about King Midas's transformation into a person with the ears of an ass? Options: A. His daughter., B. His barber., C. Dionysus., D. Apollo. Correct Option: None
Question 8: How did the barber reveal King Midas's secret? Options: A. He told the whole kingdom about it., B. He whispered it to a friend., C. He wrote it on a stone., D. He whispered it into a hole in the ground. Correct Option: None
Question 9: What happened to the barber's words after he whispered them into the hole? Options: A. They were forgotten., B. They were carried away by the wind., C. They were buried forever., D. They were heard by the whole kingdom. Correct Option: None
Question 10: How was King Midas remembered by his people? Options: A. Through statues and temples., B. Through the glittering river and the rustle of the Phrygian wind., C. Through his golden touch and ass's ears., D. Through his wise and just rule. Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

With his harebrained schemes 
and asinine dealings with the gods, King Midas ruled the ancient kingdom 
of Phrygia with an uneven hand. He was known in Greek mythology 
as a rogue ruler whose antics bemused his people

to metal in his mouth. When he picked up a loaf of bread, 
the crumbs hardened in his hand. Flinging himself onto 
his bed in frustration, Midas discovered his plush pillows 
had morphed into solid gold. Hearing his cries of frustration, 
his daughter entered the room. But when Midas reached out to her, he saw with horror that he had frozen her 
into a golden statue. Horrified at what he had done, Midas begged the gods 
to rid him of his power. Taking pity on the foolish king, Dionysus told Midas to wash 
his hands in the River Pactolus. When Midas reached into the river, 
the gold drained from his fingertips. Midas returned home 
to find his daughter alive and his palace back to normal, 
and he rejoiced. You’d think he would’ve learned 
his lesson, but just a few weeks later,
Midas blundered again, insulting the music and sun god Apollo 
when he declared Pan a greater musician. Apollo scornfully declared that the king 
must have the ears of an ass to make such a misjudgment,
and transformed Midas accordingly. Once again regretting his behavior, Midas kept his hairy ears 
hidden in public. They were seen only by his barber, who was sworn to secrecy during 
a very awkward grooming session. The barber stifled his laughter 
and fought the desire to tell someone, yet the secret consumed him. One day, he walked outside the city 
and dug a hole in the ground. Plunging his head into the earth, the desperate barber whispered,
“Midas has ass’s ears.” Soon after, a clump of reeds sprang up in the spot where the barber 
had buried his words. When the wind blew, they carried the 
echoes of his whisper through the breeze: "Midas has ass’s ears." At the sound, donkeys in the fields raised
their heads in recognition and people chuckled to themselves 
at the follies of their king. With his golden touch and ass’s ears, 
Midas was not the most respected ruler. And where other leaders were honored 
through statues and temples, his people remembered him 
a little differently: in the depths of the glittering river 
and the rustle of the Phrygian wind.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Midas angered Apollo because ______.
Options: A. He doubted his talent, B. He disrespected him, C. He sacrificed a donkey, D. He doubted his talent and disrespected him, E. He doubted his talent and sacrificed a donkey
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Who was King Midas in Greek mythology? Options: A. A wise and just ruler of the kingdom of Phrygia., B. A rogue ruler of the kingdom of Phrygia known for his antics and schemes., C. A god of wine and carnival., D. A satyr and follower of Dionysus. Correct Option: None
Question 2: What was King Midas's wish when Dionysus offered to grant him one? Options: A. To have the power to heal any illness., B. To have the power to turn anything he touched to gold., C. To have the power to control the weather., D. To have the power to become invisible. Correct Option: None
Question 3: What happened to King Midas's daughter when he touched her with his golden touch? Options: A. She was turned into a beautiful princess., B. She was turned into a golden statue., C. She was given the power to heal any illness., D. She was given the power to turn anything she touched to gold. Correct Option: None
Question 4: How did King Midas lose his golden touch? Options: A. He was punished by the gods for his greed., B. He was granted a new wish by Dionysus., C. He washed his hands in the River Pactolus., D. He was cursed by a satyr. Correct Option: None
Question 5: What was King Midas's second mistake that led to his transformation? Options: A. He insulted the music and sun god Apollo., B. He praised the music and sun god Apollo., C. He declared Dionysus a greater god than Apollo., D. He declared Pan a lesser musician than Apollo. Correct Option: None
Question 6: What was King Midas transformed into as a result of his second mistake? Options: A. A golden statue., B. A satyr., C. A god., D. A person with the ears of an ass. Correct Option: None
Question 7: Who was the only person who knew about King Midas's transformation into a person with the ears of an ass? Options: A. His daughter., B. His barber., C. Dionysus., D. Apollo. Correct Option: None
Question 8: How did the barber reveal King Midas's secret? Options: A. He told the whole kingdom about it., B. He whispered it to a friend., C. He wrote it on a stone., D. He whispered it into a hole in the ground. Correct Option: None
Question 9: What happened to the barber's words after he whispered them into the hole? Options: A. They were forgotten., B. They were carried away by the wind., C. They were buried forever., D. They were heard by the whole kingdom. Correct Option: None
Question 10: How was King Midas remembered by his people? Options: A. Through statues and temples., B. Through the glittering river and the rustle of the Phrygian wind., C. Through his golden touch and ass's ears., D. Through his wise and just rule. Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 5. 

Although the options do not exactly match, the question content and intent are similar. The ground truth MCQ asks why Midas angered Apollo, and the correct option is that he doubted Apollo's talent and disrespected him. Question 5 asks about King Midas's second mistake that led to his transformation, which is related to the reason he angered Apollo. The correct option for Question 5 is that he insulted the music and sun god Apollo, which is part of the reason he angered Apollo. 

Therefore, the index of the most similar generated MCQ is 5.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 10, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
With his harebrained schemes 
and asinine dealings with the gods, King Midas ruled the ancient kingdom 
of Phrygia with an uneven hand. He was known in Greek mythology 
as a rogue ruler whose antics bemused his people 
and distracted the gods. Midas spent his days 
in a stupor of splendor, spoiling himself and his beloved daughter
and gorging himself on feasts and wine. Unsurprisingly, he felt 
an affinity with Dionysus, god of wine, carnival, and performance. One day, Midas discovered a satyr dozing in his rose garden and drunk 
on more than the scent of flowers. Midas recognized the satyr 
as one of Dionysus’s followers and let him nurse 
his hangover at the palace. Pleased with the king’s hospitality,
Dionysus offered to grant him one wish. Midas cast a greedy eye 
over his surroundings. Despite the luxury in which he lived, no amount of precious jewels, finest silk 
or splendid decor felt like enough. His life, he thought, was lacking luster;
what he needed was more gold. The god sent the power to turn anything
the king touched to gold surging through Midas. Ecstatic, he turned to his possessions. At his lightest touch, 
the palace walls transformed, stone statues shone, and goblets glittered. He galloped through his home in a frenzy, handling each item until 
it took on a lustrous sheen. Soon the palace heaved with gold, and Midas’s delirious
laughter echoed off the walls. Exhausted and hungry from his rampage, Midas picked up a bunch of grapes from 
his newly gilded fruit bowl. But he nearly shattered his teeth, for the fruit had turned 
to metal in his mouth. When he picked up a loaf of bread, 
the crumbs hardened in his hand. Flinging himself onto 
his bed in frustration, Midas discovered his plush pillows 
had morphed into solid gold. Hearing his cries of frustration, 
his daughter entered the room. But when Midas reached out to her, he saw with horror that he had frozen her 
into a golden statue. Horrified at what he had done, Midas begged the gods 
to rid him of his power. Taking pity on the foolish king, Dionysus told Midas to wash 
his hands in the River Pactolus. When Midas reached into the river, 
the gold drained from his fingertips. Midas returned home 
to find his daughter alive and his palace back to normal, 
and he rejoiced. You’d think he would’ve learned 
his lesson, but just a few weeks later,
Midas blundered again, insulting the music and sun god Apollo 
when he declared Pan a greater musician. Apollo scornfully declared that the king 
must have the ears of an ass to make such a misjudgment,
and transformed Midas accordingly. Once again regretting his behavior, Midas kept his hairy ears 
hidden in public. They were seen only by his barber, who was sworn to secrecy during 
a very awkward grooming session. The barber stifled his laughter 
and fought the desire to tell someone, yet the secret consumed him. One day, he walked outside the city 
and dug a hole in the ground. Plunging his head into the earth, the desperate barber whispered,
“Midas has ass’s ears.” Soon after, a clump of reeds sprang up in the spot where the barber 
had buried his words. When the wind blew, they carried the 
echoes of his whisper through the breeze: "Midas has ass’s ears." At the sound, donkeys in the fields raised
their heads in recognition and people chuckled to themselves 
at the follies of their king. With his golden touch and ass’s ears, 
Midas was not the most respected ruler. And where other leaders were honored 
through statues and temples, his people remembered him 
a little differently: in the depths of the glittering river 
and the rustle of the Phrygian wind.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: When he learned the king’s secret, the barber ______.
Options: A. Didn’t tell another human, B. Told only his wife, C. Whispered it to the other barbers, D. Told everyone immediately
Correct Option: A

Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 8: How did the barber reveal King Midas's secret? 

Although the options and the exact wording of the question do not perfectly match the ground truth MCQ, the intent and content of the question are similar. The ground truth MCQ asks what the barber did when he learned the king's secret, and the correct answer is that he didn't tell another human. Question 8 asks how the barber revealed the secret, and the correct answer is that he whispered it into a hole in the ground, which implies that he didn't directly tell another human.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 11, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Thor—son of Odin, god of thunder, 
and protector of mankind— struggled mightily against his greatest
challenge yet: opening a bag of food. It’d all started when Thor, along with his fleet-footed human servant
Thjalfi and Loki, the trickster god, set out on a journey to Jotunheim, 
land of the giants. Along the way, they’d met 
a giant named Skrymir, who offered to accompany them and
even carry their provisions in his bag. But when they made camp,
Skrymir dozed off and Thor couldn’t untie the sack. Frustrated and hungry, Thor tried 
to wake the giant three times by striking his head with his hammer 
Mjolnir as hard as he could. But each time, Skrymir thought 
it was only a falling acorn and went back to sleep. The next morning, Skrymir departed and eventually, the travelers reached 
a massive fortress called Utgard. Inside the long hall, 
they met the king of giants, Utgard-Loki, who greeted his guests with a challenge: each of them was to prove they were 
the best at some particular skill. Loki went first, declaring himself 
the world’s fastest eater. To test him, the king summoned 
his servant Logi and the two were placed at either 
end of a long trough stuffed with food. Loki ate his way inward 
with blinding speed. But when the contestants 
met in the center, Loki saw that his adversary 
had not only eaten just as much food, but also the bones 
and even the trough itself. Next was Thjalfi, who could 
outrun anything in the wild. The king summoned an ethereal-looking 
giant named Hugi, who outraced Thjalfi easily. But the boy would not give up 
and demanded a rematch. This time, Thjalfi finished close behind and the king admitted he’d never 
seen a human run so fast. Thjalfi tried a third time, 
running like his life depended on it, but Hugi was even faster than before. Finally, it was Thor’s turn. The king offered him a drinking horn, saying all his men 
could drain it in two gulps. Thor raised it to his lips and drank the surprisingly 
cold and salty mead in the longest gulp he could muster. Then a second. Then a third. But the level of the mead 
in the horn was only slightly lowered. To test Thor’s renowned strength, the king
offered a seemingly easy challenge: lift his pet cat off the ground. But this cat was as tall as Thor. Every time he tried to lift it, 
it arched its back, and straining with all his godly might, 
he only managed to lift one paw. Enraged, Thor demanded 
to wrestle any of the giants. The king summoned 
the giants’ old nursemaid, Elli. Though the woman looked frail, 
Thor couldn’t overpower her and grew weaker the longer he struggled,
until he was brought to one knee. The three companions prepared 
to leave, disappointed and humbled. But as the king escorted them out, he revealed that nothing in the castle 
had been what it seemed. Loki lost the eating contest because 
his opponent Logi was wildfire itself, devouring everything in its path. Thjalfi couldn’t outrun Hugi because
Hugi was the embodiment of thought, always faster than action. And even Thor couldn’t defeat Elli, 
or old age, which weakens everyone eventually. As for the other challenges, 
they had also been illusions. The drinking horn 
was filled with the ocean, and Thor had drained
enough to cause the tides. The cat was the serpent 
that encircles the world, and Thor’s efforts shifted the earth. And Skrymir had been 
Utgard-Loki in disguise, deflecting Thor’s hammer-blows to form
valleys in the surrounding mountains. The giant congratulated 
them on their prowess, which so frightened him he would 
never allow them in his land again. Thor and his companions failed 
the challenges presented to them. But in trying to achieve the impossible, they’d pushed themselves 
harder than ever before and changed the world 
in ways no one had expected.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Thor is known as _______.
Options: A. The protector of mankind, B. The trickster god, C. The god of thunder, D. The protector of mankind and the god of thunder, E. All of the above
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was Thor's greatest challenge at the beginning of the story? Options: A. Opening a bag of food, B. Lifting a giant cat, C. Drinking from a magical horn, D. Wrestling a giant Correct Option: None
Question 2: Who accompanied Thor on his journey to Jotunheim? Options: A. Odin and Loki, B. Thjalfi and Loki, C. Skrymir and Utgard-Loki, D. Heimdall and Baldur Correct Option: None
Question 3: What was the name of the giant who offered to carry Thor's provisions? Options: A. Skrymir, B. Utgard-Loki, C. Logi, D. Hugi Correct Option: None
Question 4: What was the name of the king of giants who greeted Thor and his companions? Options: A. Skrymir, B. Utgard-Loki, C. Odin, D. Thor Correct Option: None
Question 5: What was Loki's challenge in the story? Options: A. To outrun a giant, B. To eat faster than a giant, C. To lift a giant cat, D. To drink from a magical horn Correct Option: None
Question 6: Who was Thjalfi's opponent in the running challenge? Options: A. Logi, B. Hugi, C. Skrymir, D. Utgard-Loki Correct Option: None
Question 7: What was the surprising truth about Logi, Loki's opponent? Options: A. He was a giant with superhuman strength, B. He was a god with magical powers, C. He was wildfire itself, D. He was a human with exceptional speed Correct Option: None
Question 8: What was the true nature of the cat that Thor tried to lift? Options: A. A giant cat with superhuman strength, B. A magical creature with the power of illusion, C. The serpent that encircles the world, D. A normal cat with no special powers Correct Option: None
Question 9: What was the true nature of Elli, the giant's nursemaid? Options: A. A frail old woman with no special powers, B. A giant with superhuman strength, C. The embodiment of old age, D. A magical creature with the power of illusion Correct Option: None
Question 10: What was the outcome of Thor's challenges, despite his apparent failures? Options: A. He was humbled and disappointed, B. He was praised by the giants for his prowess, C. He changed the world in ways no one had expected, D. He was banned from the land of the giants forever Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
Unfortunately, none of the generated MCQs match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content. The ground truth MCQ asks about Thor's known titles or characteristics, while the generated MCQs ask about various events or characters in the story.

However, if I had to choose the most similar generated MCQ based on the fact that it at least mentions Thor, I would say that Question 1 is the closest match, although it's still quite different from the ground truth MCQ.

never allow them in his land again. Thor and his companions failed

harder than ever before and changed the world 
in ways no one had expected.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 11, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

and protector of mankind— struggled mightily against his greatest

Thjalfi and Loki, the trickster god, set out on a journey to Jotunheim,

until he was brought to one knee. The three companions prepared 
to leave, disappointed and humbled. But as the king escorted them out, he revealed that nothing in the castle 
had been what it seemed. Loki lost the eating contest because 
his opponent Logi was wildfire itself, devouring everything in its path. Thjalfi couldn’t outrun Hugi because
Hugi was the embodiment of thought, always faster than action. And even Thor couldn’t defeat Elli, 
or old age, which weakens everyone eventually. As for the other challenges, 
they had also been illusions. The drinking horn 
was filled with the ocean, and Thor had drained
enough to cause the tides. The cat was the serpent 
that encircles the world, and Thor’s efforts shifted the earth. And Skrymir had been 
Utgard-Loki in disguise, deflecting Thor’s hammer-blows to form
valleys in the surrounding mountains. The giant congratulated 
them on their prowess, which so frightened him he would 
never allow them in his land again. Thor and his companions failed 
the challenges presented to them. But in trying to achieve the impossible, they’d pushed themselves 
harder than ever before and changed the world 
in ways no one had expected.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Thor tries to wake the sleeping giant named Skrymir by _______.
Options: A. Dropping acorns on his head, B. Tickling him with a leaf under his chin, C. Noisily searching his bag of goods, D. Striking the giant’s head with his hammer
Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 11, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Thor—son of Odin, god of thunder, 
and protector of mankind— struggled mightily against his greatest
challenge yet: opening a bag of food. It’d all started when Thor, along with his fleet-footed human servant
Thjalfi and Loki, the trickster god, set out on a journey to Jotunheim, 
land of the giants. Along the way, they’d met 
a giant named Skrymir, who offered to accompany them and
even carry their provisions in his bag. But when they made camp,
Skrymir dozed off and Thor couldn’t untie the sack. Frustrated and hungry, Thor tried 
to wake the giant three times by striking his head with his hammer 
Mjolnir as hard as he could. But each time, Skrymir thought 
it was only a falling acorn and went back to sleep. The next morning, Skrymir departed and eventually, the travelers reached 
a massive fortress called Utgard. Inside the long hall, 
they met the king of giants, Utgard-Loki, who greeted his guests with a challenge: each of them was to prove they were 
the best at some particular skill. Loki went first, declaring himself 
the world’s fastest eater. To test him, the king summoned 
his servant Logi and the two were placed at either 
end of a long trough stuffed with food. Loki ate his way inward 
with blinding speed. But when the contestants 
met in the center, Loki saw that his adversary 
had not only eaten just as much food, but also the bones 
and even the trough itself. Next was Thjalfi, who could 
outrun anything in the wild. The king summoned an ethereal-looking 
giant named Hugi, who outraced Thjalfi easily. But the boy would not give up 
and demanded a rematch. This time, Thjalfi finished close behind and the king admitted he’d never 
seen a human run so fast. Thjalfi tried a third time, 
running like his life depended on it, but Hugi was even faster than before. Finally, it was Thor’s turn. The king offered him a drinking horn, saying all his men 
could drain it in two gulps. Thor raised it to his lips and drank the surprisingly 
cold and salty mead in the longest gulp he could muster. Then a second. Then a third. But the level of the mead 
in the horn was only slightly lowered. To test Thor’s renowned strength, the king
offered a seemingly easy challenge: lift his pet cat off the ground. But this cat was as tall as Thor. Every time he tried to lift it, 
it arched its back, and straining with all his godly might, 
he only managed to lift one paw. Enraged, Thor demanded 
to wrestle any of the giants. The king summoned 
the giants’ old nursemaid, Elli. Though the woman looked frail, 
Thor couldn’t overpower her and grew weaker the longer he struggled,
until he was brought to one knee. The three companions prepared 
to leave, disappointed and humbled. But as the king escorted them out, he revealed that nothing in the castle 
had been what it seemed. Loki lost the eating contest because 
his opponent Logi was wildfire itself, devouring everything in its path. Thjalfi couldn’t outrun Hugi because
Hugi was the embodiment of thought, always faster than action. And even Thor couldn’t defeat Elli, 
or old age, which weakens everyone eventually. As for the other challenges, 
they had also been illusions. The drinking horn 
was filled with the ocean, and Thor had drained
enough to cause the tides. The cat was the serpent 
that encircles the world, and Thor’s efforts shifted the earth. And Skrymir had been 
Utgard-Loki in disguise, deflecting Thor’s hammer-blows to form
valleys in the surrounding mountains. The giant congratulated 
them on their prowess, which so frightened him he would 
never allow them in his land again. Thor and his companions failed 
the challenges presented to them. But in trying to achieve the impossible, they’d pushed themselves 
harder than ever before and changed the world 
in ways no one had expected.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Thjalfi had to prove _______.
Options: A. He was the world’s fastest eater, B. He could outrun anything in the wild, C. He could outwrestle any of the giants, D. None of the above
Correct Option: B

Question 9: What was the true nature of Elli, the giant's nursemaid? Options: A. A frail old woman with no special powers, B. A giant with superhuman strength, C. The embodiment of old age, D. A magical creature with the power of illusion Correct Option: None

He changed the world in ways no one had expected, D. He was banned from the land of the giants forever Correct Option: None

Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

in ways no one had expected.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 12, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
It was the Western Hemisphere’s 
largest empire ever, with a population 
of nearly 10 million subjects. Over an area of more 
than 900,000 square kilometers, its people built massive 
administrative centers, temples, and extensive road 
and canal systems. They did so in an inhospitable, 
extreme terrain, all without the use of wheels, 
horses, iron, or even written language. Yet within 100 years of its rise 
in the fifteenth century, the Inca Empire would be no more. According to legend, the ancestors of the Inca rulers 
were created by the sun god Inti, and they emerged
from a cave called Tambo Toco. Leading four brothers 
and four sisters was Ayar Manco, who carried a golden staff 
with instructions to find the place where 
it would sink into the ground, showing fertile soil. After many adventures 
and extensive searching, Ayar Manco and his siblings 
reached the Cuzco Valley, where the staff pierced the ground. After fighting off the fierce 
local native population, they founded their capital, and Ayar Manco became Manco Capac, 
the first Sapa Inca, or king of the Incas. Archaeological evidence suggests that the Incas first settled 
in this valley around 1200 CE. They remained a small kingdom until 1438, when they were nearly overrun 
by the neighboring Chanka tribe. The Inca king at this time, Viracocha, 
and his designated heir fled in fear, but one of his other sons remained and successfully rallied 
the city’s defenses. For his military skill, he became 
the ninth Inca ruler, assuming the name of Pachacuti, 
or "Cataclysm." Pachacuti expanded Inca rule 
throughout the Andes mountains, transforming the kingdom into 
an empire through extensive reforms. The empire’s territory was reorganized 
as Tahuantinsuyu, or "four quarters," with four divisions ruled 
by governors reporting to the king. Although the Inca had no writing, they used a complex system 
of knotted strings called quipu to record numbers 
and perhaps other information. A decimal-based bureaucracy 
enabled systematic and efficient taxation 
of the empire’s subjects. In return, the empire provided security, 
infrastructure, and sustenance, with great storehouses containing 
necessities to be used when needed. Great terraces and irrigation works 
were built and various crops were grown in 
at different altitudes to be transported all over the empire. And it was during Pachacuti’s reign that the famous estate 
of Machu Picchu was constructed. Pachacuti’s son Topa Inca continued 
the empire’s military expansion, and he eventually became ruler
in 1471 CE. By the end of his reign, the empire 
covered much of western South America. Topa’s son Huayna Capac 
succeeded him in 1493. But the new ruler’s distant military 
campaigns strained the social fabric. And in 1524, Huayna Capac 
was stricken by fever. Spanish conquistadors had arrived 
in the Caribbean some time before, bringing diseases to which 
the native peoples had no resistance. Millions died in the outbreak, including Huayna Capac
and his designated heir. The vacant throne ignited a civil war
between two of the surviving brothers, Atahualpa and Huascar, greatly weakening the empire. In 1532, after finally winning 
the Inca civil war, Atahualpa and his army 
encountered the European invaders. Although greatly outnumbered, Francisco Pizarro 
and his small group of conquistadors stunned the king’s much larger force 
with guns and horses, neither of which they had seen before. Atahualpa was taken captive 
and killed about a year later. The Spanish conquerors 
were awed by the capital of Cuzco. Pizarro described it as so beautiful that
“it would be remarkable even in Spain.” Though the capital had fallen and the native population had been
destroyed by civil war and disease, some Incas fell back to 
a new capital at Vilcabamba and resisted for the next 40 years. But by 1572, the Spaniards had destroyed 
all remaining resistance along with much of the Incas’ physical 
and cultural legacy. Thus, the great Inca empire fell 
even faster than it had risen.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Who was the first Inca ruler?
Options: A. Pachacuti, B. Topa Inca, C. Atahualpa, D. Manco Capac
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the Western Hemisphere's largest empire ever, covering an area of more than 900,000 square kilometers? Options: A. Aztec Empire, B. Mayan Empire, C. Inca Empire, D. Spanish Empire Correct Option: None
Question 2: According to legend, who created the ancestors of the Inca rulers? Options: A. Sun god Inti, B. Moon goddess Mama Quilla, C. Earth goddess Pachamama, D. Thunder god Viracocha Correct Option: None
Question 3: What was the name of the first Sapa Inca, or king of the Incas? Options: A. Ayar Manco, B. Manco Capac, C. Pachacuti, D. Viracocha Correct Option: None
Question 4: What was the name of the Inca king who expanded Inca rule throughout the Andes mountains and transformed the kingdom into an empire? Options: A. Pachacuti, B. Topa Inca, C. Huayna Capac, D. Atahualpa Correct Option: None
Question 5: What was the system used by the Incas to record numbers and perhaps other information? Options: A. Quipu, B. Writing, C. Oral tradition, D. Hieroglyphics Correct Option: None
Question 6: What was the name of the famous estate constructed during Pachacuti's reign? Options: A. Machu Picchu, B. Cuzco, C. Vilcabamba, D. Tambo Toco Correct Option: None
Question 7: Who was the Spanish conquistador who led the group that encountered the Inca army in 1532? Options: A. Francisco Pizarro, B. Hernán Cortés, C. Vasco Núñez de Balboa, D. Juan Sebastián Elcano Correct Option: None
Question 8: What was the cause of the death of millions of native peoples, including Huayna Capac and his designated heir? Options: A. Civil war, B. Disease brought by Spanish conquistadors, C. Famine, D. Natural disasters Correct Option: None

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 12, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
It was the Western Hemisphere’s 
largest empire ever, with a population 
of nearly 10 million subjects. Over an area of more 
than 900,000 square kilometers, its people built massive 
administrative centers, temples, and extensive road 
and canal systems. They did so in an inhospitable, 
extreme terrain, all without the use of wheels, 
horses, iron, or even written language. Yet within 100 years of its rise 
in the fifteenth century, the Inca Empire would be no more. According to legend, the ancestors of the Inca rulers 
were created by the sun god Inti, and they emerged
from a cave called Tambo Toco. Leading four brothers 
and four sisters was Ayar Manco, who carried a golden staff 
with instructions to find the place where 
it would sink into the ground, showing fertile soil. After many adventures 
and extensive searching, Ayar Manco and his siblings 
reached the Cuzco Valley, where the staff pierced the ground. After fighting off the fierce 
local native population, they founded their capital, and Ayar Manco became Manco Capac, 
the first Sapa Inca, or king of the Incas. Archaeological evidence suggests that the Incas first settled 
in this valley around 1200 CE. They remained a small kingdom until 1438, when they were nearly overrun 
by the neighboring Chanka tribe. The Inca king at this time, Viracocha, 
and his designated heir fled in fear, but one of his other sons remained and successfully rallied 
the city’s defenses. For his military skill, he became 
the ninth Inca ruler, assuming the name of Pachacuti, 
or "Cataclysm." Pachacuti expanded Inca rule 
throughout the Andes mountains, transforming the kingdom into 
an empire through extensive reforms. The empire’s territory was reorganized 
as Tahuantinsuyu, or "four quarters," with four divisions ruled 
by governors reporting to the king. Although the Inca had no writing, they used a complex system 
of knotted strings called quipu to record numbers 
and perhaps other information. A decimal-based bureaucracy 
enabled systematic and efficient taxation 
of the empire’s subjects. In return, the empire provided security, 
infrastructure, and sustenance, with great storehouses containing 
necessities to be used when needed. Great terraces and irrigation works 
were built and various crops were grown in 
at different altitudes to be transported all over the empire. And it was during Pachacuti’s reign that the famous estate 
of Machu Picchu was constructed. Pachacuti’s son Topa Inca continued 
the empire’s military expansion, and he eventually became ruler
in 1471 CE. By the end of his reign, the empire 
covered much of western South America. Topa’s son Huayna Capac 
succeeded him in 1493. But the new ruler’s distant military 
campaigns strained the social fabric. And in 1524, Huayna Capac 
was stricken by fever. Spanish conquistadors had arrived 
in the Caribbean some time before, bringing diseases to which 
the native peoples had no resistance. Millions died in the outbreak, including Huayna Capac
and his designated heir. The vacant throne ignited a civil war
between two of the surviving brothers, Atahualpa and Huascar, greatly weakening the empire. In 1532, after finally winning 
the Inca civil war, Atahualpa and his army 
encountered the European invaders. Although greatly outnumbered, Francisco Pizarro 
and his small group of conquistadors stunned the king’s much larger force 
with guns and horses, neither of which they had seen before. Atahualpa was taken captive 
and killed about a year later. The Spanish conquerors 
were awed by the capital of Cuzco. Pizarro described it as so beautiful that
“it would be remarkable even in Spain.” Though the capital had fallen and the native population had been
destroyed by civil war and disease, some Incas fell back to 
a new capital at Vilcabamba and resisted for the next 40 years. But by 1572, the Spaniards had destroyed 
all remaining resistance along with much of the Incas’ physical 
and cultural legacy. Thus, the great Inca empire fell 
even faster than it had risen.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The Spanish Conquistadors captured the Inca Atahualpa in what year?
Options: A. 1492, B. 1532, C. 1570, D. 1471
Correct Option: B

even faster than it had risen.

Correct Option: A

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Archaeologists believe that the Incas first settled in Cuzco in what year?

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the Western Hemisphere's largest empire ever, covering an area of more than 900,000 square kilometers? Options: A. Aztec Empire, B. Mayan Empire, C. Inca Empire, D. Spanish Empire Correct Option: None

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 13, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
From sailors who were turned into pigs, nymphs that sprouted into trees, and a gaze that converted 
the beholder to stone, Greek mythology brims with shape-shifters. The powerful gods usually changed 
their own forms at will, but for mortals, the mutations 
were often unwanted. One such unnerving transformation 
befell the spinner Arachne. Arachne was the daughter 
of a tradesman who spent his days dying cloth 
the deepest shades of purple. She had a flair for spinning 
the finest threads, weaving them into flowing fabric, and creating magnificent tapestries. People flocked to watch her hands 
flying across her loom, as if thread sprung directly 
from her fingertips. But as praise for her work grew, 
so did her pride. Arachne could often be heard 
boasting about her skills, declaring that her talent surpassed 
anyone else’s—mortal or divine. She refused to see weaving 
as a gift from the gods. Rather, she flaunted it 
as her own personal genius. Unfortunately, the goddess of wisdom 
and crafts, Athena, overheard Arachne 
making these claims. Planning to teach 
the ungrateful girl a lesson, Athena disguised herself as an old woman
and stole amongst the mortals. She berated Arachne in public— how dare the weaver claim
herself greater than the gods? But Arachne only laughed, 
barely looking up from her loom. Provoked, the old woman threw off
her cloak to reveal her true form. If Arachne insisted on defaming the gods, Athena would challenge her 
to a contest directly. Masking her shock at the appearance 
of the grey-eyed goddess, Arachne accepted the challenge. Athena drew up her own glittering loom 
as a great crowd gathered to watch. The weavers began, 
eyes fixed and shuttles blurring. Athena conjured 
wisps of cloud from above and slender threads of grass 
from below in a spectacle of strength. She wove tremendous scenes 
that showed the power of the gods: Poseidon riding the waves, Zeus firing thunderbolts, and Apollo hurtling across the sky. In Athena’s splendid tapestry, 
the glory of the gods dwarfed mortal life. But Arachne had no interest 
in boosting godly egos. Her tapestry showed the gods
abusing their power: squabbling amongst themselves, drinking and bragging, and meddling in the lives of mortals. She represented Zeus as a philanderer,
transfiguring himself to ensnare women: a swan for Leda, a bull for Europa, a shower of gold for Danae. Arachne then turned
to the misdemeanors of other gods, from Pluto’s abduction of Persephone to Bacchus’s wild pursuit of Erigone. Even though she cast the gods 
in the most unflattering light, Arachne’s work shone 
with her dazzling skill. Her tapestry was almost alive, filled with movement 
and lustrous colors that winked triumphantly. When Athena saw Arachne's undeniably
better and flagrantly subversive work, she flew into a rage 
and turned on the human weaver. Arachne’s glee dimmed as she felt her body
shrinking and contorting. Her fingers waved wildly 
as her arms stuck to her sides, and black hair
sprouted all over her body. The goddess left Arachne with a single 
spool of thread unfurling from her belly, a slim reminder of her human talent. For challenging the assumption
that the gods were untouchable, Athena had shrunk her adversary 
into the first spider. To this day, Arachne and her children spin
out her penance— or is it undaunted persistence?— in the shadows of giants.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Arachne was ______.
Options: A. A noblewoman, B. An apprentice, C. A slave, D. A self-taught weaver
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is a common theme found in Greek mythology? Options: A. The struggle for power between mortals and gods., B. The transformation of mortals into animals or objects., C. The creation of the world and the origin of humans., D. The great wars between rival city-states. Correct Option: None
Question 2: Who was Arachne, and what was she known for? Options: A. A goddess of wisdom and crafts, known for her beautiful tapestries., B. A mortal weaver, known for her exceptional skill and pride., C. A queen of a ancient city-state, known for her bravery in battle., D. A priestess of a powerful god, known for her spiritual guidance. Correct Option: None
Question 3: Why did Athena disguise herself as an old woman and confront Arachne? Options: A. To praise Arachne's exceptional weaving skills and offer her a reward., B. To teach Arachne a lesson for her pride and lack of humility., C. To challenge Arachne to a contest and prove her own superiority., D. To ask Arachne for guidance on how to improve her own weaving skills. Correct Option: None
Question 4: What was the outcome of the contest between Athena and Arachne? Options: A. Athena's tapestry was deemed superior, and Arachne was praised for her effort., B. Arachne's tapestry was deemed superior, but Athena was declared the winner due to her divine status., C. Arachne's tapestry was deemed superior, and Athena was enraged by the outcome., D. The contest was a tie, and both Athena and Arachne were praised for their skills. Correct Option: None
Question 5: How did Athena punish Arachne for her pride and lack of humility? Options: A. By turning her into a statue and placing her in a temple., B. By taking away her weaving skills and rendering her unable to create., C. By shrinking her into a spider and forcing her to spin threads for eternity., D. By banishing her from the city and forcing her to live in exile. Correct Option: None
Question 6: What was the main theme of Arachne's tapestry? Options: A. The glory and power of the gods., B. The beauty and wonder of the natural world., C. The abuses of power by the gods and their interference in mortal lives., D. The great deeds and accomplishments of mortal heroes. Correct Option: None
Question 7: How did Arachne's tapestry differ from Athena's? Options: A. Arachne's tapestry was more colorful and vibrant, while Athena's was more subdued and restrained., B. Arachne's tapestry was more focused on the gods, while Athena's was more focused on mortals., C. Arachne's tapestry was more critical of the gods, while Athena's was more celebratory., D. Arachne's tapestry was more abstract and symbolic, while Athena's was more realistic and representational. Correct Option: None
Question 8: What was the significance of the spool of thread that Athena left with Arachne? Options: A. It was a symbol of Arachne's punishment and her forced labor as a spider., B. It was a reminder of Arachne's human talent and her exceptional weaving skills., C. It was a gift from Athena to help Arachne in her new life as a spider., D. It was a magical object that would allow Arachne to return to her human form. Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is the moral of the story of Arachne and Athena? Options: A. That pride and lack of humility will be punished by the gods., B. That exceptional talent and skill will be rewarded by the gods., C. That mortals should always show respect and deference to the gods., D. That creativity and self-expression are essential to human flourishing. Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the legacy of Arachne in the story? Options: A. She is remembered as a great weaver and artist who challenged the gods., B. She is remembered as a cautionary tale about the dangers of pride and lack of humility., C. She is remembered as a symbol of the power of creativity and self-expression., D. She is remembered as a mortal who was transformed into a spider and forced to spin threads for eternity. Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 2: "Who was Arachne, and what was she known for?" 

Although the options do not exactly match the ground truth MCQ, the question intent is similar. The ground truth MCQ asks about Arachne's identity, and Question 2 also inquires about Arachne's identity and her notable characteristics.

The correct index is: 2

**Transcript**:
From sailors who were turned into pigs, nymphs that sprouted into trees, and a gaze that converted 
the beholder to stone, Greek mythology brims with shape-shifters. The powerful gods usually changed 
their own forms at will, but for mortals, the mutations 
were often unwanted. One such unnerving transformation 
befell the spinner Arachne. Arachne was the daughter 
of a tradesman who spent his days dying cloth 
the deepest shades of purple. She had a flair for spinning 
the finest threads, weaving them into flowing fabric, and creating magnificent tapestries. People flocked to watch her hands 
flying across her loom, as if thread sprung directly 
from her fingertips. But as praise for her work grew, 
so did her pride. Arachne could often be heard 
boasting about her skills, declaring that her talent surpassed 
anyone else’s—mortal or divine. She refused to see weaving 
as a gift from the gods. Rather, she flaunted it 
as her own personal genius. Unfortunately, the goddess of wisdom 
and crafts, Athena, overheard Arachne 
making these claims. Planning to teach 
the ungrateful girl a lesson, Athena disguised herself as an old woman
and stole amongst the mortals. She berated Arachne in public— how dare the weaver claim
herself greater than the gods? But Arachne only laughed, 
barely looking up from her loom. Provoked, the old woman threw off
her cloak to reveal her true form. If Arachne insisted on defaming the gods, Athena would challenge her 
to a contest directly. Masking her shock at the appearance 
of the grey-eyed goddess, Arachne accepted the challenge. Athena drew up her own glittering loom 
as a great crowd gathered to watch. The weavers began, 
eyes fixed and shuttles blurring. Athena conjured 
wisps of cloud from above and slender threads of grass 
from below in a spectacle of strength. She wove tremendous scenes 
that showed the power of the gods: Poseidon riding the waves, Zeus firing thunderbolts, and Apollo hurtling across the sky. In Athena’s splendid tapestry, 
the glory of the gods dwarfed mortal life. But Arachne had no interest 
in boosting godly egos. Her tapestry showed the gods
abusing their power: squabbling amongst themselves, drinking and bragging, and meddling in the lives of mortals. She represented Zeus as a philanderer,
transfiguring himself to ensnare women: a swan for Leda, a bull for Europa, a shower of gold for Danae. Arachne then turned
to the misdemeanors of other gods, from Pluto’s abduction of Persephone to Bacchus’s wild pursuit of Erigone. Even though she cast the gods 
in the most unflattering light, Arachne’s work shone 
with her dazzling skill. Her tapestry was almost alive, filled with movement 
and lustrous colors that winked triumphantly. When Athena saw Arachne's undeniably
better and flagrantly subversive work, she flew into a rage 
and turned on the human weaver. Arachne’s glee dimmed as she felt her body
shrinking and contorting. Her fingers waved wildly 
as her arms stuck to her sides, and black hair
sprouted all over her body. The goddess left Arachne with a single 
spool of thread unfurling from her belly, a slim reminder of her human talent. For challenging the assumption
that the gods were untouchable, Athena had shrunk her adversary 
into the first spider. To this day, Arachne and her children spin
out her penance— or is it undaunted persistence?— in the shadows of giants.

Options: A. Farming, B. Fabric, C. Wisdom, D. Love
Correct Option: C

out her penance— or is it undaunted persistence?— in the shadows of giants.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Athena disguised herself and stole amongst the mortals in order to ______.
Options: A. Admire Arachne’s work anonymously, B. Hear Arachne’s boasting for herself, C. See if Arachne was a better weaver than she was, D. Steal Arachne’s talent for herself, E. See if Arachne was a better weaver than she was and steal Arachne’s talent for herself
Correct Option: E
